case_name: Civil Appeal Nos. 1710 of 1967 and 1986 of 1968

facts.text: Mahendra Prasad obtained a licence for electrification of Chhapra town in 1932.

anchor.surface_text: One Mahendra Prasad obtained a licence for electrification of the-Chhapra town which. was granted to him in 1932.

facts.text: Licence assigned to Janardhan Prasad Varma after death of Mahendra Prasad in 1936.

anchor.surface_text: The licence was thereafter assigned to Janardhan Prasad varma after the death of his father-Mahendra Prasad in 1936.

facts.text: Licence assigned to Chhapra Electric Supply Co., Ltd., which went into voluntary liquidation in 1944.

anchor.surface_text: This licence was subsequently assigned to the Cnhapra Electric Supply Co., Ltd. which, however, went into voluntary liquidation in 1944.

facts.text: Five persons entered into oral partnership agreement to purchase electrical undertaking in name of Murli Prasad before public auction.

anchor.surface_text: But before the date of public auction, it is alleged that five persons,. namely, Ayodhya Prasad, Murli Prasad Respondent No. 1, Parasnath. Prasad, Gurbharan Shah and Nandkishore Prasad entered into an oral agreement of partnership to purchase the electrical undertaking in the name of Murli Prasad,

facts.text: Shares in partnership: Ayodhya 8 annas, Murli Prasad 4 annas, Parasnath 2 annas, Gurbharan Shah 1 anna, Nandkishore 1 anna.

anchor.surface_text: the share of Ayodhya was 8 annas, that of Murli Prasad 4 annas, Parasnath Prasad had 2 annas and Gurbharan Shah and Nandkishore Prasad bad one anna each.

facts.text: Electrical undertaking sold by official liquidator to Murli Prasad on September 15, 1944 for Rs. 4,10,000.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter the electrical undertaking was sold by the official liquidator on September 15,1944 to Murli Prasad as his was the highest bid of Rs. 4,10,000/-

facts.text: Partners contributed to purchase money in proportion to shares: Ajodhya Rs. 2,05,000, Murli Rs. 1,02,500, Parasnath Rs. 51,250, Gurbharan Rs. 25,625, Nandkishore Rs. 25,625.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter each of the partners including Murli Prasad companytributed in proportion to their respective shares in the partnership to make up the total sum of Rs. 4,10,000/-. ... Ajodhya Prasad Gupta Rs. 2,05,000/- Murli Prasad Rs. 1,02,500/- Parasnath Prasad Rs. 51,250/- Gurbharan Shah Rs. 25,625/- and Nandkishore Prasad Rs. 25,625/-

facts.text: Oral agreement incorporated into registered partnership deed on July 10, 1945 (Exhibit G), last instalment paid July 13, 1945.

anchor.surface_text: It also appears that before the last instalment of Rs. 2,50,000/- was paid on July 13, 1945, the oral agreement entered into between the partners was incorporated into a partnership deed executed on July 10, 1945 and registered under the Indian Registration Act  Exhibit G .

facts.text: Nandkishore Prasad retired, share taken by Gurbharan Shah.

anchor.surface_text: Nandkishore Prasad, however, retired from the partnership with the companysent of all the partners and his one anna share was taken over by Gurbharan Shah.

facts.text: In 1950, Rs. 1,50,000 paid by Ajodhya for new plant; Murli and Parasnath sold 1 anna each to him, shares adjusted: Ajodhya 10 annas, Murli 3 annas, Parasnath 1 anna.

anchor.surface_text: It also appears that in 1950 a further sum of Rs. 1,50,000/- was urgently required for taking delivery of some new plant and machinery which had arrived at the Chhapra Railway Station. Murli Prasad and Parasnath Prasad expressed their inability to companytribute the sum of Rs. 1,50,0001- in proportion to their shares, so this amount was also paid by Ajodhya Prasad Gupta to whom Murli Prasad and Parasnath Prasad sold one anna share each out of their respective shares. Thus, the share of Ayodhya Prasad increased to 10 annas while that of Murli Prasad and Parasnath Prasad reduced to 3 annas and one anna respectively.

facts.text: Second partnership deed executed and registered on August 31, 1950 (Ext. 9).

anchor.surface_text: This re-allocation of shares became the occasion for execution of a second partnership deed on August 31, 1950- which was also registered under the Indian Registration Act Ext. 9.

facts.text: Partnership dissolved on May 13, 1953 (Ext. C).

anchor.surface_text: The partnership Act on May 13, 1953, Ext. C.

facts.text: Ajodhya Prasad and Murli Prasad entered partnership as Karta of joint families; shares divided among family members.

anchor.surface_text: One other fact must also be stated at this stage. and that is, Ajodhya, Prasad and Murli Prasad being,. Kartas of their respective joint, familities, had. entered into partnership in that capacity. The 10 annas share held by Ajodhya Prasad and 3 annas share hold by Murli Prasad were divided among the members of their respective joint families. ...

facts.text: Electrical Inspector stated partnership illegal, Government cancelled licence.

anchor.surface_text: it appears that some time after this revised partnership was registered, the Electrical Inspector, Government of Bihar, addressed a letter to Murli Prasad in which he stated that the partnership was illegal. and void as it companytravened the provisions of the Indian Electricity Act and that, therefore, the Government did number recognise the partnership. The Government ultimately cancelled the licence.

facts.text: Proceedings under s.144 CrPC decided in favour of Ramagya Prasad Gupta and partners on April 14, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: This attempt gave rise to proceedings under s. 144 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, which, however, were decided on April 14, 1954, in favour of Ramagya Prasad Gupta and the other partners.

facts.text: Parasnath Prasad instituted Title Suit No. 68 of 1954 on May 28, 1954 for dissolution and accounts.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter it is alleged that Murli Prasad got Parasnath Prasad a partner and son-in-law of Murli Prasads brother to institute Title Suit No. 68 of 1 954, on May 28, 1954. This suit was for a declaration that the partnership had been dissolved by service of numberice on the partners and for rendition of accounts by Ramagya Prasad Gupta principally and by other partners.

facts.text: Government revoked licence under s.41 of Electricity Act, powers/liabilities determined under s.51A.

anchor.surface_text: During the pen- dency of the suit, as stated earlier, the Government of Bihar acting under s. 4 1  of the Indian Electricity Act, 1910-hereinafter referred to as the Act-revoked the licence of Murli Prasad with the result that according to s. 5 1  a  of the Act all powers and liabilities of the licensee stood determined.

facts.text: Receiver appointed, took over concern from Murli and Ramagya.

anchor.surface_text: Parasnath Prasad the plaintiff in that suit prayed for appointment of the Additional District Magistrate, Chhapra, as receiver. The Court granted his prayer and the Receiver in due companyrse took over the electrical companycern from Murli Prasad and Ramagya Prasad.

facts.text: Government purchased undertaking on October 20, 1955, deposited Rs. 3,00,000 in court.

anchor.surface_text: After the Receiver had taken possession, the Government decided to purchase the undertaking on October 20, 1955 and deposited on the same day a sum of Rs. 3,00,000/- in the Court as part of the purchase money payable to the owners of the undertaking.

facts.text: Murli Prasad filed Title Suit No. 94 of 1956 on November 5, 1956 claiming sole ownership and entitlement to purchase money.

anchor.surface_text: Murli Prasad thereafter filed a Title Suit No. 94 of 1956 on November 5, 1956, for a declaration that he being the sole licensee, was the exclusive owner of the undertaking, and as such be was the only person who Was entitled to receive the entire price paid or payable by the Government in respect of the assets of the Chhapra Electric.

facts.text: Trial Court decreed Suit 68/54, dismissed 94/56 and 113/57 on February 10, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: All the three suits were thereafter companysolidated and tried together. They were also disposed of by a companymon judgment dated February 10, 1959 passed by the 5th Additional Subordinate Judge, Chhapra. The Trial Court decreed Parasnath Prasads Title Suit No. 68/54 and dismissed Murli Prasads Title Suit No. 94/56 and Nandkishore Prasads Title Suit No. 113/57.

facts.text: Patna High Court reversed Trial Court, declared Murli sole entitled to money, holding partnership illegal.

anchor.surface_text: These appeals are by certificate against the judgment of the Patna High Court which reversed the Judgment and decree of the Trial Court in Title Suit NO. 94 of 1956 filed by the first respondent-Murli Prasad. ... This deci- sion was based on the view that the partnership companytravened the provisions of the Act and was accordingly illegal and void.

facts.text: Supreme Court appeals: CA 1710/67 and 1986/68 by certificate from High Court judgment dated May 7, 1965.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal Nos. 1710 of 1967 and 1986 of 1968. From the Judgment and Decree Order dated the 7th May, 65 of the Patna High Court in Appeals from Original Decree N03. 160 and 161 of 1959 and in First Appeal No. 160 of 1959 respectively.

facts.text: Murli Prasad claimed he alone paid entire auction money, partners were employees; partnership illegal.

anchor.surface_text: In this suit Murli Prasad had averred that it was he and he alone who had,paid the entire auction money for the purchase of the undertaking on July 13, 1945 and thereafter he became the sole licensee in charge of the undertaking and that Ramagya Prasad Gupta was a mere employee and servant under him. The partnership was also characterised as illegal and void.

facts.text: Supreme Court held partners entitled to share compensation in proportion to shares in 1950 deed.

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly allow these appeals, reverse the judgment an decree-of the High Court and dismiss Suit No. 94 of 1956 with companyts, We hold that the first respondent Murli Prasad is number entitled solely to the whole of the companypensation money, but that all those whose names appear in the partnership deed of August 31, 1950, or the legal representatives or assignees of such of them who are dead, are otherwise entitled to share the companypensation money in proportion to their respective shares as specified in the said document.
This attempt gave rise to proceedings under s. 144 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, which,

holdings.text: The appeals are not barred by res judicata under s.11 CPC or general principles because the subject-matters of Title Suit No.68/1954 and Title Suit No.94/1956 are different.

anchor.surface_text: All these aspects need not be considered in these appeals because, in our view, the subject-matter of Title Suit No.68 of 1954 and that of Title Suit No. 94 of 1956 are entirely different. Even if the issues

holdings.reasoning_summary: Subject-matter of Suit 68/54 was dissolution and accounts during subsistence of licence; Suit 94/56 concerns entitlement to compensation after revocation and purchase; common issues do not make subjects same; issues 4,9,12 survive.

holdings.text: Murli Prasad is not the sole licensee entitled to entire compensation; partners contributed capital and are entitled to share in proportion to shares in 1950 deed.

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly allow these appeals, reverse the judgment an decree-of the High Court and dismiss Suit No. 94 of 1956 with costs, We hold that the first respondent Murli Prasad is not entitled solely

precedents.citation: Ramagya Prasad Gupta v. Murli Prasad 1

anchor.surface_text: This question was companysidered by this Court. in Ramagya Prasad Gupta v. Murli Prasad 1 where by a majority, Vaidialingam Palekar, JJ., Mathew, J. dissenting, held that the appeal companyld number be proceeded with and must. be dismissed.

precedents.case_name: Ramagya Prasad Gupta v. Murli Prasad
precedents.cited_proposition: appeal abates wholly when legal representatives of a necessary party respondent are not brought on record
precedents.cited_holding: held that the appeal could not be proceeded with and must be dismissed

anchor.surface_text: the view expressed by the Lahore High, Court Full Bench in Lakshmi v. Bhuli 1 has been cited and it was submitted that this view was approved by this Court in Narhari v. Sankar 2 which it is submitted, has been followed in various decisions of the different High Courts.

precedents.cited_proposition: when two suits tried together and disposed by common judgment, dismissal of one appeal does not create res judicata for the other appeal
precedents.cited_holding: There has been in substance as well in form but one trial and one verdict... it will be a travesty of justice to stifle the hearing of the appeal

anchor.surface_text: this view was approved by this Court in Narhari v. Sankar 2 which it is submitted, has been followed in various decisions of the different High Courts. As against this view, it is claimed that this Court subsequently in Sheodan Singh v. Mst. Ddryao Kaur 3 took a different view

precedents.cited_proposition: where there has been one trial, one finding and one decision, there need not be two appeals even if two decrees drawn up; time bar of one does not bar the other by res judicata

precedents.citation: Sheodan Singh v. Mst. Ddryao Kaur 3

anchor.surface_text: this Court subsequently in Sheodan Singh v. Mst. Ddryao Kaur 3 took a different view, but according to the learned Advocate for the appellants, this case did number companysider the companyrectness either of Narharis supra decision

precedents.case_name: Sheodan Singh v. Mst. Ddryao Kaur
precedents.cited_proposition: dismissal of appeals from some suits on technical grounds bars other appeals on res judicata where common issues on title
precedents.cited_holding: the High Court was right in dismissing the appeals as being barred by res judicata

precedents.citation: Budhu Lal v. Deccan Banking Company Ltd 1

anchor.surface_text: A Fall Bench of the Hyderabad High Court in Budhu Lal v. Deccan Banking Company Ltd 1 to which one of us was a party had occasion to companysider the question that where money has been paid under the instrument which has been held to be void

precedents.case_name: Budhu Lal v. Deccan Banking Company Ltd
precedents.cited_proposition: section 65 Contract Act applies to recover money paid under ab initio void agreements, including those with unlawful consideration
precedents.cited_holding: money paid in such circumstances can be recovered; s.65 applies when agreement discovered to be void even if ab initio void

precedents.citation: Harnath Kaur v. Inder Bahadur Singh 2

anchor.surface_text: the decision of their Lordships of the Privy Council in Harnath Kaur v. Inder Bahadur Singh 2 and the observations in the 7th Edition of Pollock and Mullas Indian Contract

precedents.case_name: Harnath Kaur v. Inder Bahadur Singh
precedents.cited_proposition: agreements discovered to be void include those ab initio void

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly allow these appeals, reverse the judgment an decree-of the High Court and dismiss Suit No. 94 of 1956 with companyts, We hold that the first respondent Murli Prasad is number entitled solely to the whole of the companypensation money, but that all those whose names appear in the partnership deed of August 31, 1950, or the legal representatives or assignees of such of them who are dead, are otherwise entitled to share the companypensation money in proportion to their respective shares as specified in the said document.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeals allowed; High Court judgment and decree reversed; Title Suit No. 94 of 1956 dismissed with costs; Murli Prasad not entitled to entire compensation; partners/legal representatives/assignees entitled to share compensation proportionally per 1950 deed after paying liabilities.
directions: Reverse the judgment and decree of the High Court
Dismiss Suit No. 94 of 1956 with costs

Partners whose names appear in partnership deed dated August 31, 1950, or their legal representatives/assignees entitled to compensation money in proportion to shares after deducting outstanding liabilities of Chhapra Electric Supply Works
